item.description:
In our fifth and final segment on American philosophy Charles Sanders Peirce we will take a look at his late work on Pragmatism. We will concentrate on his 1905 essay "What Pragmatism Is" from the Monist Pragmatism series. If anyone would like to do additional readings on his late Pragmatism the following are recommended:

I. 1905-06 Monist Pragmatism series

1. What Pragmatism Is (see above)

2. Issues of Pragmatism

3. Mr. Peterson's Proposed Discussion (available if you have access to JSTOR).

4. Prolegomena to an Apology for Pragmaticism

some of these may be available in the Open Library collection of The Monist.

II. The Harvard Lectures on Pragmatism (1903) (available from Amazon).

 

In addition to looking at Peirce's views on Pragmatism we will also step back and look at Peirce's philosophy as a whole. Is it possible to define the essence of Peirce's philosophy? What would that look like?
